Voters in Thailand went to the polls today for a snap parliamentary election.
The country's Prime Minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, called the vote three years early, hoping to silence critics who accuse him of corruption and want him to step down.
A wave of protests against him has dampened business and scared off tourists.
NPR's Michael Sullivan reports that today's vote may not calm things down.
The often abrasive and combative Thai Prime Minister was re-elected just over a year ago with the biggest mandate in Thai history.
Much to the chagrin of his critics who claim Thaksin has used his five year long rule to enrich his family and friends at the expense of the nation and it's democratic institutions.
Thaksin denies any wrongdoing, but the critics case was bolstered by the January sale of the Thaksin family's telecommunications empire to a Singapore firm for nearly two billion dollars tax free.
Since then, the mainly Bangkok-based opposition has held near daily rallies in the capital, demanding that Thaksin resign, rallies that have drawn as many as 100,000 people.
But Thaksin refuses to bow to what he calls mob rule and instead called an early election to, as he put it, let the people decide.

The three main opposition parties boycotted today's election but encouraged voters to check the abstention box on their ballots.
That's because Prime Minister Thaksin says he'll step down voluntarily if he receives less than 50 percent of the vote.
